titleproper.value:
Guide to the William Marshall memorial collection
                    <num>1985.019</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Nicholas Pavlik (2011); updated by John Zarrillo (2014)

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2014-09-30T11:35-0400</date>

extent.value: in two folders, two loose volumes, and one oversize box.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: William Marshall (1813-1895) was a prominent Brooklyn businessman who established L. Waterbury & Company in 1835 and the Williamsburg City Fire Insurance Company in 1853. He also served on the Boards of Directors of several other companies. The William Marshall memorial collection primarily consists of materials relating to the death of Willliam Marshall in 1895, including sympathy notes and resolutions from the Boards of Directors of several companies, obituaries of Marshall, and an oversize memorial album compiled by the Board of Directors of the Williamsburg City Fire Insurance Company.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); William Marshall memorial collection, 1985.019, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Marshall resided at the corner of 296 Clinton and Greene Avenues for 50 years with his wife, Jane Montgomery, whom he married in 1839. Their four children were Martha A. Place, William Marshall, Jr., George Marshall, and Chauncey Marshall. William Marshall died on June 9, 1895 and was buried at Green-Wood Cemetery.

The William Marshall memorial collection primarily consists of materials relating to the death of Willliam Marshall in 1895, including sympathy notes and resolutions from the Boards of Directors of several companies, obituaries of Marshall, and an oversize memorial album compiled by the Board of Directors of the Williamsburg City Fire Insurance Company. Most of the obituaries of Marshall are compiled in an oversize scrapbook. Also included is a volume entitled 
                <emph render="italic">Notable New Yorkers</emph>, compiled by Moses King in 1899 and featuring portraits of several prominent New York City residents from various disciplines and fields. The collection contains four portraits of members of the Marshall family.
